bibl.title: Letter from Henry A. Christian to Philip Showalter Hench, June 10, 1948

div1.p: Christian discusses his personal relationships with a number of the yellow fever investigators. He notes that it was not highly unusual for a student to complete the University of Virginia medical course in one year, as Reed did.

div1.head: Letter from Henry A. Christian to Philip Showalter Hench, June 10, 1948
div1.opener:
HENRY A. CHRISTIAN, M. D.
20 CHAPEL STREET
BROOKLINE 40, MASSACHUSETTS
June 10, 1948
Dr. Phillip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have read with a great deal of interest your paper entitled
“Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever” in the Journal of Alpha Omega
Alpha for May '48. In it I have found a vast amount of information which I
did not know about and you have presented it in a very interesting way.

It appealed to me very much because with a considerable number
of those to whom you refer I had very pleasant personal relations. Walter Reed
himself I never knew, but Carroll was a good friend of mine and I saw him often
in the early days of the Association of American Pathologists and Bacteriologists,
of which I was a charter member because I happened to be an assistant in the
Pathological Laboratory at the Boston City Hospital in the year in which it was
organized, 1902 as I recall it. Carroll probably was also an original member
and anyhow an early member. Then Jefferson R. Keane (usually called “Ranny”). is an old friend of mine,
his half brothers and sisters were boyhood playmates of mine in Lynchburg, Virginia,
though at that time he had already gone into Medicine and I never saw him in
Lynchburg, but there was a period in which he lived here in Boston in which I
saw him very frequently. Loazear was an instructor of mine in bacteriology when
I was a medical student at the Johns Hopkins and all of the students liked him
very much. General Wood, as you probably know, was a Harvard graduate and had
what is not such a pleasant recollection now to the Boston City Hospital, the
experience of having been asked to resign as a house officer because he went
ahead without orders and did a tracheotomy on a diphtheria patient or at least
HENRY A. CHRISTIAN, M. D.
20 CHAPEL STREET
BROOKLINE 40, MASSACHUSETTS
-2-
that is as I remember it. In later years he was a patient of Harvey Cushing
and several times was at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, where he eventually
died following the last operation on his brain tumor, so I knew him in that way
besides meeting him from time to time occasionally in other relationships. It
may be of interest to you to know that his brain tumor, which was a very slow
growing one, developed considerableenough symptoms for the late Dr. Arthur Cabot to
explore him a considerable period before Cushing first operated on him. while Custinig was in Baltimoire. Cabot's
trephine as it turned out just missed the tumor because the tumor was not
immediately under where he had made the trephine wound. Cabot was one of the
members of a medical dinner club which met monthly and membership in which I
had the good fortune to have beginning back in 1909 with such men as
R. H. Fitz, F. C. Shattuck and many others very prominent in the Harvard Medical
School as fellow members.

In your paper you refer to Reed as having completed the medical
course in a single year. That really was not very unusual. Most of the good
man who went to the University of Virginia did it and many of them subsequently
went on to other medical schools such as the University of Pennsylvania or
Bellevue. Had I gone to the University of Virginia the year after I graduated
from college, that is in 1895, it still was possible for a man to do this,
though I do not know who was the last one to do it. At that time the medical
course was two years. However, I did not go there and spent another year in
preparation and entered the Johns Hopkins Medical School in the autumn of '96.
His youth, of course, is outstanding, I am sure, in regard to the graduation from
the University of Virginia Medicine School, though of course all graduates in
HENRY A. CHRISTIAN, M. D.
20 CHAPEL STREET
BROOKLINE 40, MASSACHUSETTS
-3-
those early days were young because very little was required of them in the way
of preparation for entrance into the medical school.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Henry A. Christian.
